item.title: Steam Breaks Yet Another User Record by Passing 42m Concurrent Users
item.content:encoded:
Just a week or so after setting a new record for concurrent users (CCU), Steam has now broken that record as well, passing a major CCU milestone in the process.

A quick look at the SteamDB charts for overall players shows that the platform hit an all-time high of 42,042,778 players yesterday, comfortably passing the 42-million-player barrier as well.

As a reminder, Steam last broke its CCU record on January 5th, when the platform registered a high of 41,816,052 players simultaneously online. It looks like the meteoric rise in popularity of Valve's platform is showing no signs of slowing down, despite Steam entering its 23rd year in 2026.

As noted by user Alejandro LL over on Bluesky, the in-game player count peak record was also broken last week, with 13.4 million players enjoying games on Steam at the same time at one point. That's only a very, very slight increase over last week's figure, but it's still impressive.

By this metric, it's safe to say that Steam is very much the most popular PC gaming storefront, and players are buying games in their droves on Valve's platform as well.

Some of last year's best-selling and highest-grossing Steam games include perennial favorites like GTA Online and PUBG: Battlegrounds, as well as much-vaunted single-player RPG Kingdom Come: Deliverance II, which achieved some pretty impressive sales numbers.

However, Steam's best-seller list was also rife with games that used generative AI, an issue that continues to cause deep divisions; some slam AI for its environmental impact and low-quality asset generation, while others consider it to be a boon during development.

Steam has also had a somewhat controversial year in other areas, having been accused of a hypocritical review policy by No More Robots' Mike Rose, as well as an opaque internal review process by Horses developer Santa Ragione.

item.title: Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot Sales Smash Through the 10m Barrier
item.content:encoded:
Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot sales have reached a brand new milestone, developer CyberConnect2 and publisher Bandai Namco have announced, so it looks like the game is still going strong despite being almost six years old.

In a message on social media earlier today, Bandai Namco revealed that Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot has sold over ten million copies since launching back in January 2020. As is often the case with sales, this number applies to both the physical and digital releases of the game, and it includes all platforms as well.

The new sales total means Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot has managed to rack up another two million sales for itself since July 2024, which is a testament to the enduring popularity of the Dragon Ball IP, I guess.

If you're not familiar with Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot, it is, as you've probably already surmised, an action RPG based on the long-running Dragon Ball series (the creator of which, Akira Toriyama, sadly passed away in March 2024 aged just 68).

The game follows the events of the Dragon Ball Z anime series and includes four major arcs as part of its base offering, namely the Saiyan, Frieza, Cell, and Buu Sagas. Originally available on last-gen machines, it netted itself a PS5 and Xbox Series X|S release in 2023.

Extra storylines from other Dragon Ball media, including the likes of Dragon Ball Super and Dragon Ball Daima, are available as DLC, with the latest expansion taking players to Daima's Demon Realm.

The first part of said DLC is already out for you to try, and the second part will be arriving in just a few days, so you won't have to wait too long to witness its conclusion.

If you want to check out Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot, you can do so right now on PC, PlayStation, Xbox, and Nintendo Switch. Make sure to check out our review to find out what our Will thought of it back in 2020.
